name: HTTP and Web Basics
description: Understand how the web works: HTTP requests and responses, headers, status codes, and TLS/HTTPS. Essential knowledge for working with APIs and web services.

learning_steps.title: How HTTP Works
learning_steps.description: Understand the HTTP request/response cycle: methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE), headers, body, and how clients communicate with servers.

learning_steps.title: Status Code Categories
learning_steps.description: Know the status code categories: 2xx (success), 3xx (redirect), 4xx (client error), 5xx (server error). Memorize common codes: 200, 201, 301, 302, 400, 401, 403, 404, 500, 502, 503.

learning_steps.title: Common HTTP Headers
learning_steps.description: Understand common headers: Content-Type, Authorization, Accept, Cache-Control, User-Agent. Know how headers control request/response behavior.

learning_steps.title: TLS/SSL Explained
learning_steps.description: Understand how TLS encrypts HTTP traffic: certificates, certificate authorities, the TLS handshake, and why HTTPS matters for security.

learning_steps.title: curl for HTTP Testing
learning_steps.description: Master curl for HTTP debugging: curl -v (verbose), curl -I (headers only), curl -X POST -d (POST with data), curl -H (custom headers). Try: curl -v https://httpbin.org/get

learning_steps.title: Inspect Network Traffic
learning_steps.description: Use browser DevTools Network tab to inspect HTTP traffic. Observe request/response headers, timing, and payload data on your favorite websites.

questions.prompt: Explain the difference between HTTP status codes 401 and 403, and when you would return each.
scenario_seeds: Your API returns 403 for unauthenticated users, but a colleague thinks it should be 401. Who is correct?
A user complains they can't access a resource after logging in. What's the difference between 'not logged in' and 'logged in but not allowed'?
You're implementing role-based access control. When should the API return 401 vs 403?
questions.grading_rubric: Must explain 401 means unauthenticated (identity unknown) AND 403 means unauthorized (identity known but not permitted) AND give appropriate use cases.

questions.prompt: What is HTTPS and why is it important? Explain how TLS provides security.
scenario_seeds: A client asks why their website needs HTTPS if they're not handling payments.
Your team is debugging a certificate error in production. Explain what certificates do and why they matter.
A developer suggests disabling TLS verification in tests 'because it's just internal.' Explain the risks.
questions.grading_rubric: Must explain HTTPS encrypts traffic AND TLS provides confidentiality and integrity AND certificates verify server identity AND explain why this matters even for non-sensitive data.

test_knowledge_prompts: Quiz me on HTTP status codes
